author.literal: = Low German. M. Dan. = Middle Danish. M. Du. = Middle Dutch. M.E. = Middle English. M.H.G. = Middle High German. M.L.G. = Middle Low German. M. Sco. = Middle Scotch. M. Sw. = Middle Swedish. Norse = New or Modern Norse. N. Sco.

O. Dan. = Old Danish. O.E. = Old English. O.F. = Old Frisian. O. Fr. = Old French. O. Ic. = Old Icelandic. O.N. = Old Norse. O. Nh. = Old Northern. O. Nhb. = Old Northumbrian. O.S. = Old Saxon. O. Sw.

note: = present participle. pret. = preterite. pron. = pronounced. prep. = preposition. pl. = plural. q.v. = quod vide. Scand. = Scandinavian. Sco. = Scotch. S.S. = Southern Scotland. sb. = substantive. Sw. = Swedish. vb. = verb. W.Norse = West Norse. W. Scand. = West Scandinavian. W.S. = West Saxon. > = developed into. < = derived from. E.D.S. = English Dialect Society. E.E.T.S. = Early English Text Society. S.T.S. = Scottish Text Society.

author.literal: BYSNING, _adj._ strange, monstrous, terrible, Douglas, I

note: M.E. biseninge, ill-boding, monstrous, from O.N. _býsna_, to portend, Norse bisna, to marvel over.
O.N. _býsna_, to portend, _býsn_, a strange and portentous thing. Norse bysn, a prodigy, bysning, curiosity. See the adj. Cp. Shetland _sóni-bosni_, O.N. _sjonar-býsn_, a marvel.
title: _sb._ a strange person, an unusually unfortunate person

author.literal: CAPPIT, _vb.
O.N. kapp, contest, zeal, _deila kappi við_, strive with. Norse kapp id. kappa, reflexive, to race. Dan. kamp, O.E. camp, cempam.

container-title: _pr. p._ driving, from care, caire, to drive
note: O.N. _köyra_, O. Ic. keyra, Norse _køyra_, to drive, ride, O. Ic. keyrsla, a driving, Norse _kjørsel_, id. Cp.
title: pret._ strove
The Sco. word exhibits W. Scand. assimilation of mp to pp, the form kapp, however, also existed in O. Sw. and exists in N.Dan
a capper is one who excels. This is probably the same word

note: Dunbar's Complaynt, 43. Deriv. from cast. O.N. kasta.

O.N. klubba and klumba, Norse klubba, Dan., Norse klump. Cp. Eng. clump. Söderwall gives _klubba, klobba_, probably M. Sw. Cp. N.Dan. klubbe.

note: Scand. Also appears to some extent later in E. Scand. Eng. club is Scand. See Skeat.
title: Exhibits assimilation of mb to bb which is general in W

author.literal: costlike. O.N. kostligr, costly, choice, desirable. O. Sw. kosteliker, O. Dan. _kostælic_, N. Dan. kostelig

note: Cp. Norse kreva, to dun.
title: _vb._ to demand payment of a debt, to dun. A regular Sco. use of the word. O.E. crafian is a loanword from Scand

author.literal: O.N. daska, to strike, sb. dask, a strike, Norse daska, Dan., Sw. daska, M.E. daschen. See Bradley's Stratmann. DE, DEE, _vb._ to die, M.E. deyen. Undoubtedly a Scand. loan-word.

note: *daujan. I think, however, with Kluge, that if the word had existed in O.E. it would have appeared earlier. See Kluge P.G.(2)I, 933. O.N. _döyja_, Norse _döi_, O. Dan. _döia_, Dan, _dö_. On M.E. deyen see Brate.
title: _vb._ to strike

title: _sb._ the stake for which one plays

O.N

author.literal: Rather W. Scand. than E. Scand. CHYNGILL, gravel. A Norse word. DAPILL, gray. A W. Scand. word. DYRDUM, uproar. W. Scand. The word is also found in Gael. Furthermore the form is more W. Scand. than Dan. Cp. _dýr_ and _dør_. DOWLESS, worthless. Duglauss a W. Scand. word. DUDS, clothes. Not found in Dan. or Sw. ETTLE, aim at. W. Scand. meaning. O. Dan. _ætlæ_ meant "ponder over." FARRAND, handsome.

author.particle: have not found the word in

editor.literal: FELL, mountain. W. Scand. more than E. Scand. GANE, be suitable. O.N. gegna. Vb. not found in Dan. GYLL, a ravine. O.N. gil. Is W. Scand. HEID, brightness. O.N. _hærð_. Icel. and Norse. HOOLIE, slow. O.N. _hógligr_. Not in Dan. or Sw. KENDILL, to kindle. Ormulum kinndlenn is from O. Ic. kendill (Brate). LIRK, to crease. I

O.N. _p[-o]ki-net. _ Not Dan. RAMSTAM, indiscreet, boisterous. Both elements are W. Scand. SCARTH, cormorant. W. Scand. TARN, a lake. Distinctively Norse. TYNE, to lose. O.N. _týna_. Distinctively Norse. WAITH, booty. O.N. _væiðr_.

note: WARE, to spend. N. verja. W. Scand. WICK, to cause to turn. O.N. vikja. Not Danish. (b). The following words are W. Scand. in form: BOLAX, hatchet. O.N. _bolöx_. The O. Dan. word has the vowel u, _bulöx_. BOWN, O.N. _búinn_, cp.
title: This meaning is Icelandic and Norse
POCKNET, a fishnet

author.literal: etc. The O. Dan. word was boin. The form in Orm. is _b[-u]n_, a Norse loanword. BUSK, to prepare, has W. Scand. reflexive ending sk. BUTH, O.N. _búð_. The O. Dan., O. Sw. vowel was o

O.Sw. _hiärne_. ILL, WILL. Both show assimilation of ld to ll. Cp. O.N. _illr, villr_, but Dan. ilde, vild. RUND, ROOND, is rather the O.N. rond than Dan. rand. SER, SEIR corresponds better to O.N., O. Ic.

container-title: Norse diall. it is u. CAPPIT shows W. Scand. assimilation of mp <

_sær_. This change of e to _æ_ in Dan. was, however, late, i.e., in the last part of the 10th Century. See Noreen P.G.(2)I, 526. SLAK, O.N. slakki. Shows W. Scand. assimilation of nk > kk. STAPP, O.N. stappa. Has W. Scand. assimilation of mp >
note: dronkne, drone, but N.Dan. drukken. HARN corresponds better to O.N. hjarni than to umlauted Dan. hjerne,
cappit. STERT is O.N. sterta. Cp. Dan. styrte. WANDRETH is nearer to O.N. _vandræði_ than to O. Dan. *_vandraþ_ (Brate), from which N.Dan. vanraad.
title: _grouf < grúfu_; bowk < _búkr_; stroup < _strjúpr_; dowless < duglauss
_boð_ and bodh, so in modern Dan. diall
assimilation of mb < bb. DRUCKEN exhibits W. Scand. assimilation of _nk > kk_
_sér_ than to O.Dan

note: e appears as u in studdy. See word list. O.N. e (from older _æi_) > _[-e]_ in hailse. e + g > e written a, _ai:_ e.g., haine, gane (to suit).
title: e remains in sprent. O.N. e becomes i in lirk, kitling, and before ng in ding, flingin, hing, and also in skrip, styddy. O.N. e > _æ_, written a, in dapill, clag. Cp. sprattle in Burns. > _æ_ before r in ware. > a before r in karling. O.N. e > i in neefe (_nieve_

_[-o]_ > _[-u]_, written o, oo, u, _eu_: crove, rove, unrufe, hoolie, hulie, lufe, ruse, roose, sleuth, tume. O.N. _[-o]_ > ou in clour. _[-o]_ > oy in toym (Bruce), exact sound uncertain. _[-o]_ + l > ow in bow

note: in thrist (O.N. _þrýsta_). _[-æ]_.
title: _[-y]_ regularly > _[-i]_, written i, _y_: lythe, tyne, sit, skyrin, snite
_[-y]_ appears as _[-e]_ (_ei_) in neiris, exact sound not certain. Cp. _[-y]_ before st > _[)i]_

note: in rad, red, radness, etc. DIPHTHONGS. ai.
title: _[-æ]_ remains in hething. _[-æ]_ > e in sait. _[-æ]_ > e, e

container-title: O.N. ai > i in nyte (?). O.N
note: ai is represented by i before r in thir. Cp. Cu. thur. O.N. ain > en initially in enkrely. _öy_.
title: ai > _[-e]_, written a, ai, ay, _ei_: bait, bein, bayt, blaik, dey, grane, graip, graith, heid, laif, lairet, lairing, lak, laiching, thwaite, waith, slaik, swage, raise, tha

note: monophthongation. ou, au.
title: _öy_ > _[-e]_, written e, _ai_: careing, dey, smaik. _öy > e_ in yemsel (_yhemsell_), may be a case of Dan

note: _oy_: e.g., soym, doif, goilk, loip, etc. O.N. _ou > u_ in gukk, vb. formed from gowk (?). jo.
title: au is regularly ou, ow in Sco.: blowt, douff, dowff, gowk, gowl, loup, louse, nowt, rout, rowste, soum. Very frequently appears as oi

note: _stjorn_). _jo > ei_ in leister. Appears as i in the N. Sco. word shiel. ju.
title: jo before r > a in starn (O.N

note: b) THE OLD NORTHERN CONSONANTS. b.
title: ju > _[-u]_ in stroop. ju > i in skyle
Is lost after m in gylmyr. b > p initially _pirrye._ d

note: ld > ll in caller. g.
title: Is lost after n in hansell. An epenthetic d appears after n in solande, _ythand_; after l in boldin and rangeld

container-title: O.N. g disappears after n in titlene. g > ch in bawch, lawch. On O.N. a + g, o + g, e + g, see the vowels
title: g regularly remains g before guttural and palatal vowels alike. g > _[*g]_ before a palatal vowel in _gen[*g]eld_, yhemsel
p regularly remains p. p > ph finally in sumph

note: Cp. also laiching. O.N. ks (_x_) > ss in assletooth, wissle. On O.N. sk, see s.
title: k regularly remains k. k > ch finally in screch

author.literal: O.N. _ð_

note: _ð_ is lost in mauch. O.N. _þ_ initially remains in thrist, thra, thraif, tha, thir, thwaite, _wan-threvin_. _þ_ > t in tytt, tangle.
title: _þ_ quite regularly > _th_: baith
_ð_ > d medially and finally in eident, ydlanlie, heid, red, duds, stud
s regularly remains s. s > ch in chyngill (?
n always remains, nd is not assimilated to nn

note: golk, dolf. An excrescent l appears in gylmyr.
title: Medially and finally generally remains. O.N. l after o > _w_: bowdyne, bowne, bow. l very frequently takes the place of w medially
